posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

—I’d like to ask a bit about the environment you played in. Looking at the picture you shared with us, it looks like you sat with your legs crossed while you played?

MON: Yes, that’s how I played.
—Sitting cross-legged like that and playing for a long time, didn’t your legs start to hurt or get numb?

MON: In my case, that didn’t happen.
—Did you choose that posture because playing on an arcade cabinet with your elbows bent is straining, but sitting cross-legged like this allowed you to keep them straight?

MON: No, that wasn’t it. I find playing on an arcade cabinet very easy, and it's the standard for me. I just found the cross-legged posture the easiest way to emulate that.
—I see you play on a tate’d CRT…

MON: I do pretty much all my gaming on a CRT.
—Right, HD TVs still have problems with screen lag/delay.

MON: Yeah. Especially with the 2nd loop of Death Label, there’s parts where the speed of your reaction time is being pushed to the limit, so you want to minimize any display lag.
MON’s setup.
—I noticed your joystick there is the HORI Real Arcade Pro. Have you made any modifications to it?

MON: I’ve made one small adjustment, actually. Not with the electronics, but I adjusted the microswitches to change the play in the stick by adding spacers.
—Was this to reduce the play in the stick?

MON: Not necessarily… there’s still some play there. It was just to make it easier for me personally. (laughs)
—Did you swap out the buttons or the stick itself?

MON: No, I didn’t change anything there.
—That’s somewhat unusual.

MON: It's often said among gamers that “the best stick for STG is Seimitsu, and the best for fighting games is Sanwa.” But personally, I think that in the end whatever is easiest for you to control is best. So this time I used a Sanwa stick.

posts.sub: How do you feel about save states?
posts.com:
I know that save states are a classic topic of discussion on /vr/ due to being somewhat controversial, with the main argument against them being that their use is cheating and therefore takes away the legitimacy of one's run, and I have to agree, you're not truly beating the video game you used save states on, it wasn't the intended experience by the developers. However, one can use save states in many different ways and I believe some qualify more as cheating than others, and in the end there's always another topic of discussion, and that is if the fact that it's cheating matters more than one's enjoyment. Anyways, save states are used for a variety of reasons:

1. Save whenever faced with an obstacle so that you take no damage at all.
2. Save only at the start of a level to replicate unlimited continues and avoiding getting sent back to the beggining.
3. Save only so that you don't have to input a long password every single time you come back to your run.
4. Save only when you absolutely must leave and want to pick up from where you left off.

Of course there are more uses, but these are the main ones I can think off. I used to do #1 when I got into emulation as a kid, but eventually it got shallow and I stopped. I'll only do #3 if the passwords are long, because in general I love inputting them. I've never used #4. However, #2 is the most interesting to me, and from my experience it can improve the experience, depending on what you're playing. If I'm playing something really good, then I don't mind getting sent back to the begging, because the early stages are fun, but if I'm playing something mediocre or bad, I feel that recreating unlimited continues through save states is better than quitting altogether.

posts.com: Consequence of failure is an integral part of design for most games (especially retro games in question). Using them as easy checkpoints defeats the purpose of challenge entirely. Even if you're doing it to "save time," ask yourself: are you playing games because you actually enjoy the experience? Why would you want a game you enjoy to be over quicker? Why would savescumming a bad game make it any more fun? It's not like most retro games offer much in the way of intriguing plots (on the level of other forms of media especially) so using them because you "want to see the ending" is just robbing yourself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
- CRTs are no longer produced because they have inferior picture quality versus LCDs
- CRTs emit dangerous levels of X-rays or other forms of radiation
- CRTs always have easily-visible flicker
- CRTs always cause eyestrain
- CRTs always make a high-pitched squealing noise
- CRTs contain lethal amounts of electricity, even when unplugged
- CRTs need calibration more than two to three times a year
- Overall CRT black levels are not superior to LCDs because ambient light ruins CRT black levels
- Analog CRTs have more processing time than digital LCDs due to poor RAMDAC performance
- Afterimages caused by phosphor decay are extremely annoying and are a significant downside of CRTs
- Sending an improper mode (resolution or refresh rate) to a CRT can cause permanent damage
- CRTs cannot have touchscreens
- 4:3 is so bad that nobody should use a non-widescreen CRT
- The Sony GDM-FW900 is the only CRT worth owning
- Curved CRTs have objectively inferior picture quality versus flat CRTs with otherwise equal specifications
- CRTs should not be used because they are heavier and deeper than LCDs
- CRTs have severe reflections because they do not have matte coats
- CRTs can be permanently damaged by nearby magnets
- You will not have sex in 2023
- Analog signals limit a CRT's resolutions and refresh rates and negatively effect picture quality
- Heavy metals are used in CRT glass to reduce radiation

> Analog CRTs have more processing time than digital LCDs due to poor RAMDAC performance
perhaps true for graphics cards and monitors, but that is the fault of the graphics card, not the CRT.
an NTSC signal directly drives the electron beam. it don't get no faster than that. video game consoles used a technique called "double strike" to get 240p instead of 480i, essentially sending an invalid NTSC signal to get the beam to draw the same lines instead of alternating. hence those scanny ass scanlines.
> CRTs cannot have touchscreens
they sure as fuck did, and they existed since the early 80s. they were common on ATM machines.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ExKowj2g8N8
> CRTs contain lethal amounts of electricity, even when unplugged
fuck yeah they do =)
seriously be careful if you decide to fuck around inside of one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9550859
It's functionally identical to an F-type connector that you typically associate with RF input. It's the same signal just shaped differently.

Any RF box will do. Or actually, you don't even need a box; the purpose of that box was so that you could hook up your console without having to give up access to your TV channels. But since analogue TV isn't a thing anymore, it's a moot point. For instance you can just hook a Nintendo or Atari straight into the coax port without a box and it'll work just fine (actually better since less chance of interference from a shitty box)

If you have an s-video port then you don't need a s-video to scart adapter. posts.com:
>>9558619
completely normal, especially for the top and bottom. its called overscan. you'll notice most old games don't have status bar information in the very top and bottom of the screen because of this reason.
a little bit is fine and normal: about 8 pixels or one square in any direction. just center it the best you can.
FCEUX by default cuts off the top and bottom 8 pixels of the screen by default, it was assumed TVs just were this way.
WARNING: you don't want to go crazy adjusting it either: if you make it perfect for your NES, your SNES and PlayStation will be out of whack, etc etc. analog signals were never perfect.

you might live in an area where there just aren't many crts, but here are some more options:
-check your listings daily for several months, including curb alerts, garage/yard sales (if such things exist where you live), and estate sales

-expand your search area and do a road trip
-ask your friends and relatives if they have any laying around
-see if you can't get any from a local recycling facility, including any organizations that accept electronic donations for reuse
-thrift stores, although some don't accept crts anymore
-flea markets and swap meets
if all that fails or if it's easier, you could pay ebay price and hope the seller packages it properly

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9565176
>So PVM is just an even better Trinitron?
"Trinitron" is a brand of CRT. "PVM" is a line of Sony monitors, some of which contain Trinitron CRTs, with others using flat panel LCDs or OLEDs.
>They're pretty small though
Sony made PVMs ranging from 8 inches all the up to 42 inches. They also have a line of BVMs which go up to 32 inches.
>I guess the trade-off is you have to choose between great image and larger screen, or even better image and smaller screen?
Other way around actually. Larger PVMs typically have better image quality, though, image quality has little to do with screen size. Resolution/dot pitch is what matters. Typically, though, the smaller the screen the lower the resolution.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9565779
Use something you can run 240p test suite on or maybe a dvd with test patterns on it.
Is the picture dim at max brightness? Does it have color purity issues?
Is the geometry good? Do lines look like lines and circles look like circles? Does the image look tilted?
How is the convergence? It's typical to have problems but is it noticeable if you're not looking at a test pattern?
Some of this stuff is fixable if you know what you're doing, but I'd avoid anything with big geometry problems or a dim picture.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9574938
That sounds nice. That kind of equipment seems nice to have, unfortunely all I have access to is a Wii. It does have component though. Also I did some more tweaking, and now I think I'll settle on this process (using ffmpeg):

>scale video to 656x448 (assuming it's already in a 4:3 ratio)
>crop to 640x448 (you don't see the 8 pixels on the sides anyway due to overscan, and the new width prevents subtitles from going off the sides of the screen)
>pad out the rest of the video to 720x480 to match DVD standard
>in WiiMC video options turn "Set VI Width to 720" to "On"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9574515
the yoke is part of the crt on the back of the tube with the deflection coils on it. sometimes the yoke of a crt will shift a little in a way that makes the picture bow at the top. i've seen it myself on two wegas in person. now, sony sets also tend to have in-depth service menus. i'd guess that you need the remote, but you can check the service manual for your model. the service menu might have an option called VCEN. i'm calling it bowing, but there's also a service menu option called VBOW which is different. if the service menu doesn't have the VCEN option or if you can't access it, you can also address the bowing by carefully adjusting the yoke by hand while the set is powered on. carefully not only because of the high voltage, but also because the neck of the tube is fragile and yokes are made of plastic which gets brittle with age. here's some videos about yoke adjustment:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=otwPa-nhcTg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q2IHJfvD-70
not sure if your set has the adjustment rings, check pic related under V-CENTER and V-PIN. in your case the bowing's so small that the difference might not be worth the effort anyway. up to you. i'd recommend reading the service manual if you want to do picture adjustments anyway.

>>9554519
If they've survived until now, they should last another 50 years. They dont really have components that wear over time. Due to the high internal voltage, they would explode if they were made wrong or used garbage quality parts. The only things I can think of would be hysteresis in the yoke magnets, maybe some electrolytic capacitors might go bad.

I've got a 32" Panasonic..something. My grandparents had it around for years. At least it doesnt have the CNN logo or the 50 yard line burned into it. I've managed to hook it up to a PS2 and have been working through my DVD anime backlog. Even on the shittiest builtin composite video, color accuracy is astounding. On "Noir" I can hold up the concept art in the booklet right to the screen and its a perfect match. The only thing that hampers the experience is the occasional tearing from fast motion competing with interlacing video signal.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9585664
I love the art direction and sound design, Keiichiro Toyama is one of my favorite directors, and I genuinely cannot get into these games. I think what irks me the most is that the tank controls, especially on the PS2, have no excuse for being there in the first place. Most of the game is behind the player, so it just makes the walking unfun. You top that off with some very unfun puzzles that run entirely on videogame logic (the can of orange juice down the chute to collect the coin, o-of course!!) and dialogue that no actual human being has ever uttered and you have a very dated experience that's hard to get into.

I think with RE, even though I don't like tank controls in general, it makes perfect sense to have them. The dialogue is campy to the point that it's impossible to take it seriously, and the puzzles are well designed and you never get terminally stuck on them. It's just engaging in a way that SH never was.

>>9574470
Mine was also a 32GB Memory Card. When started to having this problems I just formatted everything and tried to start all over but didn't work. So I swapped for the 4GB Memory Card I had and everything started working fine. Installed Enso on him and passed all the files from a fresh install to the SD2Vita that I bought and made a backup for this files because if anything goes wrong I have a safety. I also removed the Memory Card and didn't install anything so now I have two backups.
In your case you don't need to do all that >>9574464 if you already Enso your Vita using your Memory Card, you can just copy all the files from your Memory Card to the microSD(after you formatted correctly) and swap the ux0: on the YAMT settings and point to the SD2Vita. After that I recommend you to stop using and remove your Memory Card and just leave him as a backup if you didn't make a backup after you hacked your Vita.
Reminder to only do this if you Enso your Vita.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9574813
They designed games around using both screens. Nintendo pushed pretty hard for devs to make use out of the touch screen feature for the lower screen, and this led to quite a lot of square pegs jammed into round holes out of obligation, ergo needless and obnoxious gimmicks foisted on the player. Dawn Of Sorrow comes to mind, the stylus adds exceptionally little to the gameplay, and it actually flows a lot better if you use a romhack which removes the mandatory stylus poking.

Eventually this would be more relaxed, and thus for a lot of games, the second screen didn't serve much more of a purpose other than being something like a map screen, inventory screen, or status screen, which you could manipulate with your stylus if you for whatever reason wanted to take your hands off of the controls.
Those could be pretty convenient and handy in some games, but they also wouldn't have suffered if they only had one screen to work with. Some games were made with the touch screen in mind, such as some drawing games, or Trauma Center, where its application is actually pretty cool and thematically well placed, but most videogames aren't the kind where using a stylus on a screen is a critical or badly needed feature.

So, a gimmick which kind of could be cool for the right kind of games, but which was widely unnecessary. I want to liken it to if the Virtualboy could have been hooked up to a TV to play the games in regular 2D, and then only early games were made with the 3D in mind while most devs just put token efforts in for the 3D and expected you to play it on your TV.

To make this post more retro, the original DS had a slot for GBA slots, of course, so beyond the thing playing DS games, you could play all your favorite GBA games, or pick up later ones for cheaper as the market was moving away from it. Also, some DS games could have some form of interaction with prior GBA titles if two relevant ones were inserted, typically bonuses in a DS sequel to a GBA game.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9586134
>Quake netplay was way more influential

OpenGL wouldn't be as big as it is without Qjuake and Quake II. Granted, OpenGL wasn't part of the original release of Quake I. The MiniGL patch was released 6-8 months later, or something. But the MiniGL patch did convince companies like Nvidia, ATi, 3DFX and other videocard developers to patch OpenGL into their drivers. Quake II came with OpenGL right out of the box. Granted, The Khronos Group have moved on to Vulkan. But OpenGL is still pretty widely used today. ID Software did not create OpenGL, it was available for things like Windows NT. But ID helped port OpenGL to the Windows9X kernel, which was adopted as an industry standard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9585008
Quake was more revolutionary. A fully 3d fps with online deathmatch was huge. It was the beginning of e-sports. It was one of the first FPS games to have multiplayer-only maps. Quake demos helped establish speedrunning as a thing. Quake pushed people to upgrade their computers, a much more popular platform than the N64. The code had such a legacy that even Half-Life 2 has some Quake code in it.

As for which aged better visually, most people probably prefer the more varied color palette of Mario 64. As for level design, Mario levels feel like a bunch of bunch of abstract block combinations, compared to Quake levels, which feel more realistic and cohesive, each with plenty of secrets and even 4 secret levels. Quake has better enemies, but I would expect it to, since it's a different genre. As for atmosphere, Mario has a fairly light and varied atmosphere, compared to the neverending darkness of Quake. Quake is significantly more replayable because of the higher difficulty ceiling, online multiplayer, and mods. As for gameplay, they're both near the apex of their genres, the 3d platformer and the boomer shooter, and you're free to prefer either.

Graphics have gotten better in both genres, and both the 3d platformer and FPS genres have undergone changes, but I see a lot of FPS fans who want to go back to the good old days of FPS when games like Blood and Quake were new. I don't think fans of 3d platformers want the genre to regress -- they're happy with the improvements made by Mario Galaxy and Mario Odyssey. So I suppose Mario 64 has aged worse, since while people like it, people want to move on from it to newer and better things, which is not something you can say of Quake, what with the interest in returning to the past with retro-style boomer shooters.

There are a few other dependencies in babel_static_functions.txt, but other than that you pretty much just inherit from SyncEnabledMonster or ChainEnabledMonster and use the appropriate hold state calls to make sure your monsters don't get their actions clobbered by signals at the wrong times. It's that simple.
As a bonus, those also include (but do not necessarily require you to use) the fear functionality.
>Also is there a reason cyberdemons and spider masterminds don't get in on the fun? Enhanced AI would be the perfect improvement to the lackluster masterminds
Honestly, for fear, it made some maps way too easy, or it had to have the thresholds set so high that it never happens. Like if you just BFG a bunch of hell knights and the sybie runs away, not fun.
For sync/chain, it just didn't seem to do much. I tested it out early on but the effects were negligible, so I removed them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9585458
>sybie
cybie*
Also, I forgot to mention: feel free to just chop out anything you don't want or rename stuff or whatever. The Hell Knight has some decent comments in it explaining what everything is and does, since it uses a little bit of everything. A lot of the stuff in Babel is fairly highly coupled, specifically for fear, but there's also things I never did like making weapons attract monster attacks and other fuckery with targeting. Once you get a grip on the basics of exactly what I did to get sync/chain to work you'll see it's fairly straightforward, honestly not complex at all. If you want to get more complex and make a mod that isn't trying to be vanilla+, but maybe a little more out there, there's a TON of things that you can do just by throwing triggers around and manipulating states. The Cacodemon, for example, uses the same kinds of signals for its dodges. You could go so far as to make paired enemies that always do complementary actions, or even potentially simple squad-based AI, that's just a lot harder than what I did and would probably blow up vanilla balance.

posts.com:
>A brush consists of several faces, each of which is defined by a plane and additional texture information. The actual geometry of the brush is only defined by the planes, of which there must be at least four. Each plane defines a half space, that is, an infinite set of points that is bounded by a plane. The intersection of these half spaces forms a convex polyhedron. Note that the actual vertices of the brush are NOT stored in the map file. The vertices are determined by BSP (or a level editing program) by computing the intersections of the planes.
What the fuck was carmack thinking with this

But aren't they translated to actual vertices in the end? It shouldn't make any difference to the performance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9586027
That's the normal way to do things. This is also how hardware rasterizes triangles: you have 3 line equations (in screen 2D space) and you test if the pixel is on the correct side of all 3 at the same time; if it is then it's inside the triangle (some details omitted).
The plane representation gives you a trivial answer to the question "is this point inside the volume?". The vertex representation gives you jack shit, and you need topology information on top because a set of vertices can define many shapes depending on how you group them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9586208
Dividing faces into polygons is one of the options to generate the picture. You can use some other rasterization method (scanline fill or ray casting, for example). Collision detection and visibility work with planes. Read something on how compiler tools process the map data from the editor, and why. If I recall correctly, Quake-related engines combine all static brushes into one complex enclosed space (the “inside” of the map where everything exists), then subdivide it with each face plane to produce many subvolumes touching each other. You can also check GoldSrc and Source documents from Valve, their principles are similar.

When you have planes, you know you have planes by definition. When you have polygons, you need additional calculations to get normals from positions of vertices (which accelerators can implement in hardware, but you can't), and, sometimes, to recover the fact that polygons belong to the same plane.

Here's what I got as a rough draft for the rules and general mapping tips.
A Serious Case of /vr/ Rules:
>Map must be made for Serious Sam The Second Encounter 1.07 version (this is the most up to date retail version you get from Steam/GOG)
>Usage of custom textures, sounds, and music is approved and encourged
>Usage of custom entities or other mods is NOT allowed. Outside of textures, sounds, and music your map should be 100% vanilla with 1.07
>Map must be beatable (duh)
>Map must have proper co-op support
>Do not make edits of existing maps
>Project host has the final say and can deny your entry if it is not up to /vr/ standards (please put some effort into your map)

Tips:
>Trigger a checkpoint whenever a new weapon is picked up to ensure everyone spawns with an "up-to-date" arsenal
>Make co-op portals for arenas that get closed off (and one-way doors for any closed off rooms/secrets so players don't get trapped)
>Aim to balance your map around Serious difficulty first, but don't be afraid to make support for other difficulties afterwards
>Also keep co-op in mind when balancing encounters
>"Hot Starts" are not that common in Serious Sam, try making a "lobby" room for players to jump around in without risk of triggering anything (useful for co-op)
>A good fight is more enjoyable than a good looking room, don't stress yourself out over brushwork
>Use the official maps as references (I won't berate you for coping models, texture work, etc. from official maps) (You can have multiple maps opened at once and switch between them in the editor)
>Get creative with secrets!

Any other important rules I might be missing for a mapping project?

The core RE audience heading into the 00s were snoy boys and a smattering of PC gaimers. Capcom bit the hand that fed them thrice in one generation by putting the first and best versions Code Veronica on the Dreamcast, morphing the original RE4 in Devil May Cry, then signing the exclusive deal with Nintendo. So a lot of it was the fox and the grapes as most people thought buying a GC for those games was not worth it. REmake and RE0 didn't come until 12 year later, and the PS2 and original PC RE4 ports were grossly inferior to the cube versions.

Hardcore RE fans hated the rejection of the classic formula and being denied the opportunity to take down umbrella. They were seething that RE4 did its own thing exceptionally well while they had some classic formula bread crumbs in the form of Outbreak 1+2 and built a cult around the brilliant, if flawed send off the Raccoon City arc.

compression isn't a bad thing by the way, it's not an insult to the cube, it just has some inherent traits. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9577528
>item slots
RE4's item management is weapon-focused; there's still just as much strategizing, but the items being managed are different. i'd argue there's more strategy because you not only choose what to hold but how you organize it. if you're going to criticize this, then tell me how realistic the fucking magic stash box in classic RE is.
>puzzles
that's literally one of the first puzzles in RE4. come on dude. this is retarded even if we ignore the fact that RE4's puzzles are the gameplay; the way you approach each encounter, not just some fucking riddle with a pre-defined answer.
>risk of dying
why is classic RE more of a survival horror game just because it inconveniences you for 5 minutes instead of 5 seconds? unlike the other games, RE4 actually records your deaths. try beating RE4 with no deaths on pro and then we can talk about survival horror.
>health and ammo
there is nothing inherently wrong with having more ammo if there are more enemies. this argument comes down to believability, in which case you're forced to reconcile the believability of classic RE's item management with the fact you're playing a series about a zombie outbreak with mutated spiders. what matters is the gameplay.
>complexity and backtracking
that image is literally one tiny area, there are tons of non-linear environments. RE4 has plenty of areas where you'll be running back through the same routes a few times; it also has large areas like the village where you can explore multiple buildings in whatever order you want. it has multiple sections with branching paths and permanent missibiles. it even has shortcuts and backtracking routes, like how you can go back to the castle to get the broken butterfly, or go back across the river to find a hidden merchant and fight dogs before you'd normally first find them. you can't even see all of the game on one playthrough.
RE4 will always be the best.

Because they took away from us the great Umbrella conspiracy story without EVER closing it properly. posts.name: Anonymous

>>9579423
This game had so much going for it. It had body part specific damage, like shooting zombies purposely in the head hurt them more. Shooting Pluto's brain (the fat Tyrant) was the only way to hurt it, and with the silenced pistol you were actually able to make the fight really easy, because Pluto, being blind, then couldn't hear where your attacks came from, making him unable to attack you. And all of this is easy to exploit, because the game has built-in support for USB mouse aiming. There was a wealth of opportunity for tactical play.

Bruce and Fong Ling were excellent characters with great chemistry, and more importantly, they were something new, blank slates. They left with a lot of untapped potential for sequels. Morpheus Duvall was a kickass boss. The Umbrella ship was a very exciting location that was used well, and the story finally properly started exploring Umbrella's other dealings outside of Raccoon City, while also showing how desperate the Umbrella bosses were getting now that government agencies around the world are hunting them after the Raccoon fuck up.

Dead Aim was totally taking the series to the correct direction, and then it was just completely ignored. That is the true tragedy here.

That part is true, Devil May Cry started life as a proposed Resident Evil 4 by Hideki Kamija, one which strayed dramatically from the Resident Evil trappings and formulas, to the point Shinji Mikami thought that it really wasn't fit for the series and that they should instead retool the game into its own thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9576472
All the hype of 'taking down umbrella' taken completely out of the hands of the players and just left to 'stock collapse'.
All the moody slow paced horror atmosphere replaced with near constant action. And this happened while the horrible live action RE movies were also being pushed. Felt like the entire formula for the entire franchise was forcibly changed to appeal to hollywood and the masses.
Inventory management changed massively, even if it was for the better.
The struggles of item limits are gone. Game throws plenty of health at you throughout and ammo can be grabbed from lots of downed enemies.
Only one serious puzzle in the game, and while RE never went as brain-teasing as SH they were still a large part of the charm that was removed.
Soundtrack isn't good, especially when compared to the games that came before it. There's no music in RE4 that makes me want to go back and re-experience it compared to every prior game. The constant action always overtakes the soundtrack, I think the only musical pieces I can remember are from water room (because you spend so much time there), robot salazar, and the starting cue for the final boss theme.
Also RE4 dragged QTE's from being a stupid Shenmuetard gimmick into the mainstream and fucked over all games for years. And I like some of RE4's QTEs.

RE4 is still god danm fantastic though. But it ignored the entire formula. Outside of silly minor things like a hidden fixed camera option for a DLC, old fans were treated like we didn't exist until 2017, and even with RE7 on it's debatable if it's a respectable evolution of the old formula or not.
Also on a more personal level, RE4's locations are ways less interesting in looks and design. Only RE4's Castle stands out. Every prior game's setting(s) were significantly more interesting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The simple and obvious answer is: no.
Reason:
They are not used by the highest level players.
If there was an advantage to using them then the top players would be using them.
They were experimented with years ago and most reports indicated no difference in winning or scoring, or inferior performance to the standard buttons.

Now, is is possible the winds could shift and if someone uses them to get a big win or a world record opinions could change.
But these buttons have been around for decades now and that hasn't happened.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9583286
The short answer is yes, the long answer is kind of. As far as buttons go, just within the conventional Sanwa stuff there's the foam pads, which change the travel and make the bottom mushy but do a good job of turning that plastic smacking into a quieter thud, and the elastomer cap style which have pretty much normal travel but are a grippier material I don't love and seem to mostly turn high pitched noises into lower pitched noises rather than being massively quieter overall. Maybe in a case with less echo it would work better, I don't know. There's a bunch of other meme options with silent keyboard switches and silicon inserts and shit as well.

Joysticks you can just flat out get non-clicking switches and only have the low pitched gate thud but the feel is different and the prices are kind of nuts. I've never bothered because ultimately the joystick isn't any louder than silenced buttons. The standard there is Hayabusa silent (I don't think you can buy them separately from a full silent Hori stick), and silent JLF high tension, but if I was buying one I'd be trying the LSQ-40.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9584327
>What changed from their usual plastic that the translucent ones that makes a different sound profile? It seemed the same for me on the outside.

The plungers are comprised of three parts with some play between them as opposed to just one solid piece of plastic like in the opaque models. When fully assembled you can even twist the translucent color top cap back and forth quite a bit. So not only do they sound rattly, they feel like it too. You can try this for yourself. Take out on of these plungers like pic related, hold it by the lower white part and then hit it like you wanted to activate the button. Now do the same with an opaque model. They're fucking ass and feel and sound so unsatisfying to play on. Switching out the plungers for opaque ones was the first mod I did right after I bought a stick that came with these pre-installed because I was so disappointed with them. The housing is fine however. It's really just the way the plungers are constructed that makes them terrible. An easy fix in the end.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9584327
Holding them in my hands again now, I have to say that I was actually too lax in my original post. The problem isn't only present when bottoming out. These buttons rattle if you so much as look at them. It gets a little better if you take the insert out from under the top cap but then you can see the little radial beam construction underneath and the loose top cap still remains somewhat annoying to me. If one really wants these for aesthetic reasons I would suggest taking them apart and carefully super glueing all the parts together. I imagine that would help quite a bit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9587037
Emulation can suffer latency issues if your configuration is poor, anyway.
I remember a lot of people complaining that they couldn't pull off rhythm combos in Mother 3 because of the latency issues in emulation.

There can be a ton of factors
>TV/Monitor display and the display mode used
>Wired or wireless controllers
>Emulator; VBA versions something newer like mGBA
>Emulator configuration like v-sync, buffer sizes, graphics renderer, whether or not you're using "run-ahead".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9580883
Eh, I sense some bitter bias here. Yes, its true that NOA and NOE during the NES years often had a bias against overt themes regarding themes and symbols of many IRL faiths and/or religions as per their pre-ESRB political correctness game censorship guidelines, which also forbade references to alcohol, illicit drug use, and, most on-screen bloodshed. However, as much as there are references to Christianity here and there, especially in the early years of the franchise, that the Cross is not an exclusively Christian symbol, just as the Six-pointed star is not exclusive to Judaism. True, the special book in the early Zelda games is literally called a "Bible", and cross imagery in a number of areas, the bulk of them in the early titles. But what makes you so damn sure that the word "Shimpu" is specifically meant to mean a Christian Priest? How fluent in Japanese are you, really? The language is often vague, its written form (aside from Kanji, which acts somewhat more like Chinese does) is a syllabary, is more reader dependent in its structure than any of the languages of Europe, and those of the Indian subcontinent, and Southeast Asia. I also add that even in the pre-Majora's mask era of LOZ, there are also other lore and folkloric beings from different parts of the world present. Fairies (Celtic and Germanic Lore) can be found in every game in the series. The Master Sword in Link to the past/Triforce of the Gods is very much reminiscent of Celtic Arthurian legend and lore. The swimming fish that raise their heads out of the water to make ranged magic ball attacks found in LOZ1 and ALTTP/Triforce of the Gods are more Japanese Kappa-inspired. Not sure about the Peahat enemies, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9587149
Definitely play in release order, but here's some guidance

>All versions
Play the Wii U GBA Virtual Console version where possible. The ROM file can be extracted and played on any emulator or GBA flash cart, and can be patched further if needed. The VC releases have small fixes, color adjustments, and allow you to access event and multi-player exclusive battle chip data by accessing the Network menu. In some cases, you need to do this for 100% completion.

OR, wait for the Legacy Collection which launches in April, which supports online battling and trading for players on the same system (Switch / PlayStation / Steam)

>BN1
The DS version called "Operate Shooting Star" with fan translation is recommended, as it smooths out some of the issues with the initial release. Most notably, includes *-code chips which act as wild cards for easier chip selection and folder building.

If you want to get through the game quickly, you can rush through the main story, exploring the internet is actually largely optional; you only need to explore about 4 or 5 of the internet zones, of which there are 16

>BN2
Nothing further needed

>BN3
You have a choice of Blue or White versions. Blue is recommended for its inclusion of an additional boss fight, and certain chip data you can acquire.

>BN4
Comes in two versions that have significantly different story events with a focus on new game+ to encounter all of them. The "Double Soul" changes you can get are exclusive depending on the game you choose.

>BN5
The DS version is recommended, which includes both versions, and multiple enhancements not found in the GBA release. You may or may not prefer the soundtrack.

>BN6
Comes in Cybeast Gregar and Cybeast Faltzer versions, which have different playstyles for their major transformations.
Playing a patched Japanese ROM to restore international cut content is strongly recommended.
https://forums.therockmanexezone.com/rockman-exe6-english-patches-t5507.html

There's usually an anon that provides a copypasta of all the good Battle Network and Starforce pre-patched ROM goodness (including 3DS .CIA versions) in Battle Network threads on /v/ and /vr/, but I don't have it handy.

Added note, if you decide to play the Star Force trilogy on DS
>SF1
Play the DX rom hack by Prof 9, restores a ton of content and merges all three versions into one game.
>SF2
Play the "Not Quite DX" rom hack by Prof 9, it alleviates a lot of the annoyances such as the infamous high encounter rate. Do not play the European version, it cuts content compared to the US release.
Also, for first time players I would recommend playing the "Zerker" version.
>SF3
No patches necessary, the game is excellent, but no European release exists.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Personally I'd have sex with:
Roll
Tron Bonne
The Wheelchair girl
The News reporter
The painter
Also Roll's mom

But onto the true essence:
The world is convincing in its set up, and built in such a way that entices you to explore each corner over and over, and the connectivity of all dungeons with the overworld give a true sense of discovery and exploration too bares real fruit, not meaningless rewards.

While American-internet discourse would wind up hinging on the globally unpopular Nintendo 64 and its mid-life game, Ocarina of Time, many experienced what it delivered and saw it done better in an earlier title. Better more realized characters, a world worth giving a shit about and a threat delivered not suddenly and with a map swapping time jump but actual changes over time. Not only did you see a world worth saving, unlike Hyrule, you saw it become more and more threatened by forces beyond your understanding and given a look into a greater world the sequel would actually deliver on, and not in a half assed way - Legends 2 is a different type of game and succeeds the original in different ways but does do many of the same things just as well. I can see why fans of 1 would find disappointment with 2, it loses one of the greatest traits - the interconnected world but does many things the original does not - namely the improvements to the core mechanics.

Legends 1 is an easy game, frankly most early 3D games are quite easy - Ocarina of Time especially so, they are often built with layers upon layers of systems to make things easier, from MMLs trivial circle strafing to Ocarina's 4 full revives at no cost to the player. Difficulty is beyond the point, what matters is everything else from characters to the world to the music to the object of your efforts being paid off. Legends does it all so well, it's amazing that it came out so early from a studio known almost entirely for their 2D efforts.

Yuro here.
Pretty rare overall in that era. The main way to get pirated stuff was to try and get stuff from Asia where Hong Kong was well known for being bootleg central. In absence of online stores, your best hope was to go to vacation in HK or in post-Doi-Moi Vietnam or in Thailand, or to have a store in your area that did imports and got non-official gear knowing it was pirate stuff or not. Crackdowns were rare because customs were pretty much incapable of telling what's what , piracy was a new concept at that point, all the authority knew were bootleg records and "home taping is killing the music industry".
Got much worse once consoles moved from cartriges to discs, for obvious reasons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9585565
>If I understand you correctly, that's just the reality of a system with such variation in mappers.
That's not really true, or at least it doesn't have to work that way. People hated on byuu for it but his cartridge folder format is perfect for something like this because it lets you define the cartridge PCB on a game by game basis. In the folder you'd have an XML that defines the PCB and then each chip would be it's own .ROM. This could just be zipped, too. This is what MAME does and it works perfectly. This way the emulator doesn't have to care about headers or formats. It can just be a base NES and the game itself informs the emulator what it's deal is. Without having to deal with headers you can "extend" the format infinitely large because each game defines itself, exactly like real carts do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9585597
The schema for the XML would still need to be extended for every new chip that could be present in a PCB. It does sound a bit more flexible than the fixed size binary headers used in most ROM formats though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Time Splitters (only on Game Cube)
>Time Splitters 2
>Quake 3 : Arena
>Half-Life : Decay (only on Playstation 2)
>Serious Sam : The First Encounter
>Serious Sam : The Second Encounter
>Metroid Prime (only on Gamecube )
>Medal Of Honor : Frontline
>Unreal Championship
>007 : Nightfire
These were the good games which looked modern and were on PS2, XBox, and Gamecube between 2000 to 2002. Certainly worthy competitors in the market (Metroid Prime maybe not aiming for the exact same market segments), but with the edge of splitscreen and online multiplayer, together with overall being a good game with good presentation, marketed strongly, I don't think there's any wonder why it did quite well for itself.

However, people forget that if you wanted a first person shooter on XBox, that Halo was the ONLY one there until 2002, where you would see a couple of middling games until roughly about a year after Halo's launch, where you'd finally see some good games on the console like Unreal Championship, Serious Sam, Timesplitters 2, etc. Thus, Halo had basically an unchallenged share of the market for a time, where its reputation did it well against middling or nonexistent competition on its home turf, letting it establish itself pretty well, with the PC port not coming until 2003, and which wasn't quite great, so if you were interested in Halo you probably wanted to get it on XBox. This would help set the stage for Halo 2 in 2004, which was a real barnburner, selling over two million units on its release day, and which had a popular and enduring multiplayer scene.

tl;dr it was a good game which in some aspects had limited competition, with a series which kept growing in popularity as it went.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You know what Halo was? The quintessential 7/10 that was released at the perfect time and on the perfect console. The only reason anybody continues to talk about this series like the second coming of the jeebus is because, for a brief window of time, it was the only semi decent game on a largely terrible platform -- and it was marketed by one of the biggest, most influential companies on earth. The game itself is painfully derivative; its sole contribution to the genre was making analog control scheme standard for console shooters. In every other way, Halo ranges from mediocre to outright bad. Let's talk about some of Halo's "innovations"...
>game begins with superhuman cyborg badass running away from every enemy he sees while human soldiers defend him, until he can find a general that gives him a weapon (and says he doesn't keep it loaded, even though he does. because uhhh... no reason at all.)
>first real level drops you into a wide open environment with absolutely 100% fuck all nothing to find, where you'll skirmish with a handful of small enemy groups and then drive a buggy and then it's over
>later levels are either most of the first few levels played in reverse, or the library, where you walk through endless blue corridors shooting the shittiest enemy ever designed for a video game for 2 hours
>every weapon is complete dogshit and outclassed in almost every way by the very first weapon you find. in fact, the only reason to ever use any other weapon is when you have no pistol ammo. at best, you might use the rocket launcher or sniper a few times in very circumstantial instances.
>no online multiplayer except on PC (which was botched), they seriously expected people to play 3-4 person splitscreen on giant empty as fuck maps unless they could convince a dozen fat retards to come to their house and play LAN (which 99% of players never did despite what anyone tells you)
This game, by the way, sold almost 1/2 as many units as Goldeneye.

>i feel like the most common misconception with halo and other arena shooters is that they're these super high skill ceiling games because they saw some old 1v1 duels or MLG highlights from back in the day when those types of people are only a fraction of a playerbase in that an average joe isn't going to be playing on the level of someone playing in the grand finals of an esports event.
I think some of that comes from how the people who were just seriously into those games kept playing with each other once everyone else moves on, and the skill and knowledge of the game just concentrates in that smaller and more focused playerbase, as you're pitting the dedicated players against each other and they keep getting better.

Then, when a later newbie outsider takes interest in the game and tries it out, they find themselves stomped by the elite old guard who know game and meta like the back of their own hand and have 10+ years of well reinforced neural pathways, which can make these scenes feel impenetrable. Less apparent in games where there's other game modes besides deathmatch and team play, but it's still easy to feel like a fifth wheel in co-op multiplayer when the experienced players do all the work while you're still trying to figure out what you're doing and how to approach it.

It's not really so much the competitive, and the old competitive players from the height of the game may very well still be able to trounce the rest of the playerbase once they readapt to the game or/and derust their gaming skills, depending on where they went in life.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9579129
Grenade buttons weren't invented by Halo, but that doesn't mean that Halo didn't have a part in popularizing them. There's many cases where an aspect may get credited to something even if it wasn't actually the first game to ever do it, often it's because the game in question did it both in a good way, and the game sold well, making a good and visible example.
You can look at FPS as a whole for this, Wolfenstein 3D gets touted as the original first person shooter, but it isn't true, aside from iD themselves having made the Catacomb 3D and Hovertank 3D games back when they were still the Gamer's Edge division at Softdisk magazine, there's simple first person shooting games on arcades and even computers and consoles which predate that.

What Wolfenstein 3D does though is put the player in a 3D space with textured walls, where they can move freely, and there's a focus on FAST gameplay, no fiddling with any stats or inventory, it's just shooting the gnutzis, avoiding getting shot as much as you can, while managing your resources and finding the exit to the next level (which may involve up to two different keys), finding treasures and secrets confers benefits of extra lives and putting yourself on your own personal scoreboard.
The gameplay is perhaps slightly too simple (hence being quickly overshadowed by Doom, which hits a fantastic balance), but more importantly it was a fast and widely available first person action game unlike any other.
Thus, it gets credit for assembling this into the very base formula that came to change the world.

Of course, nothing Halo does actually REVOLUTIONIZES anything, huge hits had done it all before, and it didn't reinvent grenade buttons, games like Team Fortress Classic already implemented those well, but it was one of those games which made the concept really take off because it was a fairly big commercial and critical hit which implemented the mechanic well and made it a prominent feature of its popular multiplayer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Halo was average at best. People thought it was amazing because they were young and impressionable when Microsoft's marketing machine kicked into overdrive to move units on the x-box, since it was the 'flagship' title.

I've played many hundreds of hours of those games in a social setting (split screen, LAN, XBL and Xlink). Why did I play so many hours on an average game? Because it was a good way to catch up with friends and let off some steam, since it geared as a party game, so people that weren't that skilled could still join and have fun.

In the group of course there were three fanboys that played even more than me, their explanations as to why it's "so awesome":

>it doesn't do everything well, but it puts together different things well
Perhaps the most honest answer, he can't point at anything in particular, he's played enough games to know Halo didn't invent much new, but likes that there isn't any major annoyances in integrating all the different systems (from controls to game balance).

>the AI
This is because the levels were heavily scripted, so for example someone might say "wow that elite took cover behind this corner there when it's shields were down, that was clever" - players don't know that Bungie just added these places into the terrain. Another level where you're on the beach, where grunts and jackals "fall back" because you shot the elite, there is actually a zone on the beach where they can retreat to baked into the game.

>the short time to kill, recharging shields/health
Honestly, I was never a huge fan of this concept but I think Halo 1 nailed it the best with the longer recharge time and and needing to venture to health packs. When they shortened the timer and fast regenerating health, for Halo 2 and beyond, it made the dynamic even worse (encourages people to just hide out of the action).

>>9579915
I don't care much for regenerating health, I find it's usually a crutch for not wanting to do better level design, but grenades being a quick button instead of its own defined weapon to manually switch to is just fucking practical and makes grenades more viable and fun. With a button I can just make a grenade throw and it automatically returns me to my weapon afterwards, that's smooth and I don't need to come to a halt, you can make the gameplay faster for it, and in return increase the challenge for the player to match their abilities.

In Half-Life, I find myself not using hand grenades all that often because that requires that I stop shooting what I'm using now and switching to another weapon, manually throwing it, and then switching back. Because of that, in the heat of combat I basically never ever use them because I don't want to let up the pressure, whereas I gladly use the grenade launcher altfire because it's very conveniently attached to my machinegun (and it also detonates on impact).
The role I end up using them for (aside from maybe demolition or setting off tripmines from around a corner), is if I have the drop on an enemy, in which case one or two grenades are my opening before lay down fire. This is useful, but more occasionally, and the grunts tend to avoid it, which in itself isn't bad, it's nice that different enemies require differing tactics and approaches, that's good, but it makes the already limited grenades still more limited.

If I instead chuck one with a dedicated press, I could maybe use it when in actual combat with the grunts, if nothing else to flush them out or suppress them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9581145
>90s and early 2000s can't be grouped together. Radically different times for PC gaming.
>Things moved really rapidly back then.

This, you can't even group the entire 90s together. Shit got outdated stupidly fast. I am not joking, a top-of-the-line PC I got in mid-90s went from being able to run anything at the highest settings to no longer meeting the minimum requirements for anything in the span of a year.

As for what it was like, mid-90s had some wild games. On top of the AAAs which usually was a shitty port of a console game, there was shelves of smaller never heard of games that many times were experimental. The 90s was also the time of gross-out humor and Nickelodeon's peak so many devs were going all over the place in their game design. Even many of the "educational" games had fun aspects to them.

DOS based games could be a mess to get working, especially later ones that used mouse, sound, cds, or even 3D acceleration. They were a lot easier to use if they had a native Windows version.

It usually sucked to get a PC port of a console game, if it even was a real attempt at a port and not a horrible re-creation it was usually a poorer experience compared to the console, just listen to the music of the PC version of Megaman X. In Windows 95 a BSOD didn't even mean you had to reboot, many of them were recoverable since it would BSOD on the slightest thing, even trying to eject a CD while it had "pending locks" (e.g. the software saying "Wait! Don't let the user eject it!") would cause it.

The 00s was far more focus on 3D, but the early 00s was a mess of 3D hardware becoming standard in PCs and drivers being a mess with a system loaded with all sorts of expansion cards. A lot of the games were ports, and very hit-or-miss. Many other more original 3D PC games could be anywhere from great, to interesting yet repetitive or hard to control, to just plain boring with 3D utterly booming but many standards of how to design a 3D game not in place yet.

>>9581124
Generally speaking there was a clear distinction between consoles and PC gaming, with fairly different titles on each system.

It wasn't profitable at the time for Devs to make games designed for (usually) one or two consoles with already massively different architecture work well on the huge variety of different hardware and drivers available for PCs in the early 90s and 00s.

PCs tended to specialise more in FPSs, Strategy games (both turn based and real time), point and click adventures (which were not great fun on consoles until the Wii), longer form RPGs and Simulators of various sorts. Consoles tended to focus much more on racers, sports games, beat em ups, platformers (both 3D and 2D) and shorter form RPGs. What you get now, which is things being played fairly consistently across multiple platforms simply wasn't commonplace. Ports from consoles generally weren't that great, ports from PC to console were often even worse.

There were of course some games that worked reasonably well on PC and Console, some that come to mind were:
- the GTA series
- The Tomb Raider series
- Resident Evil 2 onwards

At least in the second half of the 90s PC games were perceived as more mature and serious than console games. Every new Lucas Arts game on PC, whatever the genre was, was expected by gaming magazines like the second coming of Christ, and honestly for good reasons. Games like Tie Fighter or Monkey Island would not "work" on a console, even if they could technically.
Point and click adventures, RTS, FPS (at the time they were known as Doom clones) were all the rage back then.
Fightans, platformers and such were scarce and could not compete with the quality seen on consoles.

PC gaming in the early 2000s was the best fucking thing ever. Imagine growing up on your brother's NES games, and then one day, you get a Win XP computer and you're playing Command & Conquer Renegade online with 64 other people, waging huge wars in giant battlefields. There was Diablo 2, Quake 3, some of the best games ever made, all released within the span of a few years. There was crazy stuff like Ragnarok Online; I'll never forget playing it for the first time and thinking "holy shit, I'm in a virtual world with thousands of other people" while exploring this game the size of a small country, making friends and crushing on girls and starting my own shop and fighting in guild wars; that stuff may seem pretty standard now, but at the time, it was unbelievable. All of this on top of the culture of the era: it would be a friday night and you'd go downstairs, make pizza pockets, wait for Trigun or Cowboy Bebop to come on Adult Swim, boot up StarCraft on the family PC, try to sneak a beer or some liquor from your dad or smoke a cigarette without being found out... it was just a simple, wonderful time to be alive. If there's any period in my life that I could return to, it would be that magical era.

posts.com:
>>9581750
>I remember trying to save up for a Pentium with a 486 processor and a few hundred MEGABYTES of RAM. It cost $1500 - $2000 (USD)

That makes no sense. Pentium and 486 were different classes of Intel processors, the Pentium being what replaced the 486. That would be like saying you wanted to save up for an "I7-12700K with a I7-13700K Processor"

Also a few hundred megs of RAM? That is an ABSURD amount for the original Pentium. I highly doubt there were any consumer boards that could support even 128MB for the Pentium 1 back then, much less several hundred. 8 Megs of RAM was considered mid/high end for the Pentium 1 originally, 16MB later. It wasn't until the Pentium 3 that 128MB was becoming a more standard amount to have, and that was still not a budget amount. There is no way if the 486 was still relevant that you were looking at several hundred megs of RAM. The largest harddrives at the time were 1-2GB, putting several hundred megs of RAM in a system from back then is like the equivalent of having 512GB-1TB of RAM in your home PC today.

>Not him, but says who? Modern oppion?

No, just the opinion of anyone who played it and had also played the SNES version, including me back then. I thought the game was glitched or corrupted or something when I heard the cacophony of "music".

Someone already posted a comparison video, how can you listen to that ear-rape and say it's a fine port? It's not just bad, it's not just a downgrade like the soundtrack of PC FF7 was, it's so horrific it might as well just be randomly generated notes. The sprites are all fucked too. Stretched and have a washed-out look to them, making them contrast far heavier with the background and giving them an appearance of not even belonging there when viewed on a CRT.

Is it as bad a Megman 1 for DOS? Obviously not, that wasn't even a port, that was an abomination to all that is gaming. But it's up there as one of the more infamously bad PC ports back then. A modern "bad" port isn't even close to what a bad port back then was like, now a port is considered bad if it has few configuration options, is locked at 30 FPS, and basically is exactly like the console version and didn't add configuration features for the PC version. But the truly bad PC ports were back from the 80s to mid 00s.

That's not to say there weren't good ports too, but when they were bad, they were REALLY bad. Destruction Derby for example was a pretty decent port to DOS:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-FDIp6fv2oo

Rollcage wasn't bad either:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_2Fv-3M-Ees

Come to think about it, both of those were racing games by Psygnosis. I recall liking many of Psygnosis's PC games back in the day.

Point-and-click game with copious CGI, impressive production values, batshit insane plot, full voice acting, and it impressed Nintendo so much they hired a lot of the staff for their EAD team. It's Japan-only, for the moment being. Only times it got talked about before was when collector hoarders accidentally leaked a private mega folder with tons of games including this previously lost game.
Company did 3 games like these and folded shortly after. Supposedly uses a Macromedia type thing.

Some copyright troll trademarked a bunch of stuff including the logo for the game and took down most of the media about it online, and it looks more like erasing the game from existence than a prospective new release. Nearly nothing is left online.

The game is about a 5 year old American girl identifying as a bear (and portrayed as such) going to dangerous locations after hearing voices in her head. The game opens with her being refused a bus ride, that bus is bombed by terrorists and everyone is dead, the terrorists are gunned by an airplane and everyone is dead, and the girl inspects the bus and goes "It can't be helped". Then she has to avoid dying by starvation, getting hugged to death by a pedophile cop, getting killed in the crossfire of other terrorists in a public park where a schizophrenic woman thinks the heroine is daughter, and then an alien locale that defies description. I'm saddened the walkthrough was taken offline. I really want to see how this goes now that I learned more Japanese. The backstory intro roll itself (which is in English) alone is a riot.

If you like Oblivion or Skyrim, you'll probably like Morrowind as long as you don't mind reading or following directions instead of map markers.

You shouldn't play it. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9583968
>is this game worth getting into even if the combat is wonky and there's no voice acting or waypoints?
Yes. On waypoints, you are given directions on where to actually go, and if you follow those, you should be able to find your destination every time (barring I think one or two occasions in the entire game where it's wrong, in a sidequest). There's little voice acting past stock phrases, but that's fine, there's a lot of good written dialogue, you just read it with their voices in your head.

I'll also let you in on a tip, there's a website called "The Universal Hint System", it's an old one, and a very underrated one which could maybe have had more games on it, but it has Morrowind, and what it does is provide you with just a hint for a quest in the game, so that if you're stumped and clueless, you could consult this site, and it'll give you a point without spoiling the entire quest for you like a Wiki does.
https://www.uhs-hints.com/uhsweb/morrownd.php

>I feel like I'm gonna have to take notes down like I did with the Myst series but since there's so much to do so much to see
You wouldn't need to take notes, you've got a map and there's a journal which makes note of quests and what not, it even has a search function in it I'm pretty sure.
I guess though that you could jot down a few reminder notes on a piece of paper or your phone for stuff which isn't a quest thing (or not yet a quest thing), but which you want to keep in mind to return to later at some point.

The original .exe is quite buggy, so I want to suggest that you either run it with the Unofficial Code Patch, or use OpenMW, either which fix a lot of the buggy aspects, like unwanted crashes.

And you realize how a lot of the game is meant to have a balanced team as well, as a lower leveled mankey or nidoran can hold its own with Onix.

You really won't have that hard a time in RB with any of the three starters. One Charmander has ember he can power through Onix because the special stat isn't properly balanced, and Bide is a normal type move. I've done runs of RB where I just get Charmander and mash A almost the entire game and win. It takes grinding, sure, but its nothing impossible for a kid, which is why so many kids had teams that were anchored on a ridiculously leveled starter.

What was your first experience playing Doom?
>late 1994 sunday afternoon
>7yr old me, obsessed with Mortal Kombat 2
>don't read gaming magazines, out of the loop about PC games in general
>dad brings home a big box with cool artwork and floppies inside
>"drop your nintendo, anon, I've got something here"
>"nooo dad, not your simulators again"
>(I actually loved playing F117 with him but all I wanted to play at the moment was Mortal Kombat 2)
>"It's a shooter game like contra but it's in first person like you are watching the action with your own eyes, anon"
>"yeah dad, like in your simulators. This is a really stupid idea"
>dad switches on the PC. I don't like it much because "Super Nintendo has cooler games" and I'm always afraid to break it somehow. I am not allowed to switch it on and use it on my own
>Windows 3.1 starts but dad shuts it down to "free the memory"
>starts a blue-windowed shell instead
>I am looking at the game box while the game installs. It says Doom II
>some of my classmates were joking about Doom when the lights went flickering in the class. Never seen the game myself and never knew that there are two of them
>after the setup process the game is launched, first level starts, I see pic related
>"huh, these stairs look cool"
>dad moves around, shoots
>"definitely cool"
>I ask to try myself and for the rest of the session it's just me playing and dad watching me play and giving advice
>we finish the game a couple of weeks later. Keyboard only, frequently getting scared and lost in the levels, save scumming
>It's the best gaming experience in my life, thanks dad.

>>9560493
For $5000 you could get a brand new Pentium computer around 1993 and have about half left over (people didn't do this at the time). Doom only needed a 486 to run well, which hovered at around $1000 at the time, and would keep dropping. By the time Doom 2 was in stores, a 486 computer with a mouse and the memory to use it together with the game would be WELL under the $1000 mark. Not to talk about the older and much cheaper 386 machines which would run the game well enough in low detail mode and the screen size cut down a step or two, with the original game's first episode being widely available dirt cheap, or even for free. Most people probably experienced it this way, many using the 386 or even 486 at their school, university, or workplace.
That's in addition to said PC, even on the lower end, being capable of playing MANY other good games, as well as all kinds of office, work, and utility software.

To conclude, your dad should have pulled out, because clearly he couldn't afford to raise you if the prospect of playing Doom was prohibitively expensive. You must have grown up somewhere incredibly poor and undeveloped.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561281
>For $5000 you could get a brand new Pentium computer around 1993
You'll need that if you want full and consistent framerate.
>Doom only needed a 486 to run well
With basic ass 486DX-33, you needed to set the quality to minimum and reduce the window size by 25% or less to get a comfortable framerate.
>which hovered at around $1000 at the time
More like $2000 for the basic ass 486DX-33. Even a shitty 386DX would be well over $1000. A bare minimum spec PC with 486DX2 66MHz, the minimum CPU for running Doom comfortably, would run you up for almost $2500. 486SX was choppy as hell and with 486DX you needed to scale down the screen size by something like 25% and set the quality down to minimum, but it will still get choppy when the game throws more enemies at you. Not sure if using more RAM than the minimum spec of 4MB will help the game run better, I suppose it does at higher quality and resolution.
>Not to talk about the older and much cheaper 386 machines which would run the game well enough in low detail mode and the screen size cut down a step or two
More like in half or less.
>That's in addition to said PC, even on the lower end, being capable of playing MANY other good games, as well as all kinds of office, work, and utility software.
Just not Doom, it was one of the most demanding games back then. You'd have much better luck playing it on atari jaguar.

Him, his brother, and his dad, they really liked action movies and horror movies, but it took a bit of talking with his dad apparently because the whole hell and demon things rubbed him slightly the wrong way at a glance.

His brother made an argument about the demons from hell being your unquestionably evil enemy, and how the hero must obviously have great resolve and faith in god (in addition to his strength and training) to be able to fight hell on his own. Convincing enough apparently, because his dad grew fond of the game himself.
His dad was a movie buff, had lots of film on tape, even had laserdisc. He once showed us a Smith & Wesson Model 39 he got from his dad once upon a time, which he had put a pair of pearl or faux ivory grips on so the gun would be just like Vasquez's pistol in Aliens, which I thought was cool.
Anyway, if you couldn't even find a computer at school or a workplace by 1994 to play even the Doom shareware on, you'd have to be crazy backwater,.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561337
>You'll need that if you want full and consistent framerate.
If you wanted the full 35fps at all times, sure, but the vast majority of people hadn't ever experienced that with a game of that graphical fidelity (compare to Ultima Underworld). The game being able to stay consistently above 20fps was already incredibly fluid for most people at the time. Compare.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=foHUXGzHOx0

Never mind that you definitely did not have to spend up to $2500. You didn't have to buy a complete pre-built, you could build your own, even reuse components from an older computer (such as the screen, keyboard, mouse, speakers), depending on what you start out with, you could even replace the 386 on the motherboard with a 486, and a weaker 486SX can be replaced with a better 486DX, the previous one can be sold off to cover expenses. You can also save a lot by skipping a CD-ROM drive, which would start at like $200 alone by 1994, Doom was available on floppies.

If you had already invested in a 386 prior, you didn't need to spend a fortune on getting decent performance with Doom, nor did you if you had a lower end 486. Some computers with 486s could also be upgraded to Pentium, which could become relevant for later games.

>>9558129
October 1994, I was on a week long vacation from school, visiting my now dead cousin, who owned a 100 Mhz Intel 486 PC with a load of games on the HD. He was a university student at the time and had the connections to get all sorts of shit. Thanks to him I was able to play all the major releases at the time, because my own family were poorfags. Anyway...

So there was Doom, sitting on his hard drive. I was already familiar with Wolfenstein 3-D and Doom was said to be from the same guys, so, together with all the media hubbub surrounding it, I already sort of knew what to expect. I booted DOOM.EXE on my cousins MS-DOS 6.22 system and over the next few hours, my mind was fucking blown.

This thing had everything that Wolf 3-D lacked: Stairs and height differences, different levels of lighting, and actual 3 dimensional pillars. The guns had just the right amounts of balls, and the satanic imagery just the right amount of your classic 1990's edge. Video game violence was the hot topic in news at the time, so being able to play this naughty, forbidden thing at just the right age as a 14 year old teenager made you feel like a proper rebel.

I ended up staying at my cousins place the whole weekend, where I finished the full game. I came prepared: I had the cheat codes, which I copied from a video games magazine earlier at my local library, so my 1st time beating Doom was actually with cheats enabled. Even then, it was a tight experience. Even with IDDQD on, my 1st encounter with the Cyber Demon almost had me shit myself. Doom was fucking radical.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9575386
I was damaged so fucking badly by that.

A lot of people who try out games like Doom when they're really young may be provided with the cheat codes so they won't just eat shit all the time. To me, cheats quickly became a crutch and I would play any and all game with any cheats I could find, and would often shy away from games where I couldn't cheat. I was fucking bad at videogames, and I was a sore goddamn loser who couldn't cope with any setback. I wasn't a scrublord, no, for I was actually the scrubkaiser.

One day when I'm like 14 or 15, checking out Duke Nukem 3D, a game I had fooled around in with cheats before, my brother actually talks me into giving it a go without cheats. Fuck me, the experience was conclusively better, I don't think I had ever had that much fun with videogames before, and I felt like a king beating the final boss and watching Duke score a goal with his eyeball, proudly proclaiming...
>GAME OVER!

Games turned exciting in ways they weren't to me before, because I finally allowed myself to be challenged. It was lifechanging, I set out on giving them all proper goes, Doom, Goldeneye, Half-Life, Quake, Return To Castle Wolfenstein, Rise Of The Triad, and they were all amazing in ways they never were to me before.

On Final Doom, my enjoyment with that had largely been to play with no monsters and just look at things and listen to the cool music which was different from Doom 2 (I played the first one a little later), because the levels were scarier and I was a chickenshit initially. After my rehabilitation, I finally got to experience them for what they were really worth, and I would see them in a very different light.

Plutonia is a lot harder than Doom 2, but it's also super doable on UV. You just need to learn the levels before trying to play through them in one go. You need to know the levels and have a solid strategy for each fight, then it's super doable. The multitude of traps will fuck you sideways if you're not prepared for them, but there's almost always a way to handle the traps in a way that will cause you to take minimal to no damage.
For Plutonia, I suggest playing through each level while savescumming, developing an optimal path through the level and developing optimal strategies for each fight, then going back and playing through the level again in one go without savescumming.

Super Mario is an incredibly easy game to pick up and play for just about anyone, but beating it warpless is another story. It is an athletic game, after all, according to its creators.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9583294
>There isn't a single great Sega console.
Master System and Game Gear were both excellent 8bit consoles filled with classics, of course they both couldn't compare to their main competitors, NES and Game Boy respectively, but that doesn't take away from the quality of their hardware and their success in some regions of the world outside of North America and Japan, they're still quite fun to play even nowadays. Genesis/Mega Drive is still a fantastic 16bit machine with most of SEGA's classic franchises, and near perfect arcade adaptations too, it was SEGA's most succesful console for a reason, it has hardware that was ahead of its time, and a library filled with quality titles in most genres, regardless if you prefer the SNES over it or not, just the fact that it managed to rival what could be the most perfect console of all time, the SNES, shows how good it was. If you want to talk about its add-ons, the 32x really was quite bad, but the CD had some decent titles for its time. At last we have the Saturn and Dreamcast, which weren't as succesful, but the Saturn's library isn't bad, especially in Japan, and the Dreamcast had probably the best launch lineup ever.

>Sonic's gameplay never worked.
>Every blind playthrough on the internet proves
I see this take getting posted a lot nowadays, the whole "Sonic was never good" nonsense, and that's exactly what this sort of comment is, nonsense. Sonic is probably the only franchise where people seem to feel proud of themselves for being really bad at it, like it turns them into a video game connoisseur to suggest that one of the most beloved and succesful franchises of all time is somehow fundamentally flawed. You can't expect to pick up the controller and be good at it from the get go, no video game is expected to let you just do well and win right away.
