posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9584741
>But why?
Because that anon is kinda full of shit and that remark mostly applies to video games. And one of the big reasons for that is that there weren't any european actor when it comes to hardware. The closest there have been were electronics company making computers in the DOS era and a bunch of them were just locally built versions of licensed american templates. That's mostly because it's hard to grow large enough to cover all the necessary R&D when your potential market is a lot smaller than that of the US or when you aren't massively subsidized the way japanese electronics companies were. So no one was large enough to produce much. Amstrad and Sinclair tried but that alone wasn't enough to create an ecosystem distinct and large enough in Europe. It doesn't help that consumer technological lag was very real in plenty of places in Europe : a lot of local electronics companies were slow to adopt new formats and importing was too pricey for many. So if you lived in Italy, Portugal, Spain, parts of France or Germany in the 90s, you'd be mostly surrounded by 80s tech. In the 2000s, the Eurozone ended up making importing much easier too.
That mostly leaves devs. Some have pretty actively tried to make somewhat distinctive types of games. Think Quantum Games or Eric Chahi's games with an emphasis on narrative and stripped-down gameplay. There is also a whole scene of computer devs in eastern Europe, which was especially active in the years after the fall of the USSR when the markets there opened and your average Ivan could get a computer that isn't an east-german Robotron piece of shit.
tl;dr :
>pre-Eurozone disparate market made it impossible for local tech to grow in a unique way, no one was big enough to do unique hardware (save for maybe Sinclair or the Minitel project)
>tech penetration among consumers took forever
>the devs that try to grow unique local stuff usually end up with bombs or pretty niche success

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Nowadays the concept of completion in video games is more widespread than ever before, with pretty much every single release, no matter what genre it's from, having tons of achievements/trophies for players to go after, making that percentage number go up and up until it reaches 100% and they can claim that they've completed what they are playing. Of course, completion isn't a modern concept though, and the idea that one could do more than simply reach the credits has been around for a long time, some say that you have to do it on the hardest setting, while others claim it has to be a 1CC, but the general consensus is more simple, collect everything that there is to collect.

What do you consider to be a 100% completion run? (Hard; 1CC; Collecting; Other).
Have you ever deliberately gone for 100% in a video game before? If so, which 100% run are you most proud of?
Did you ever give up on getting 100% on a video game? If so, what was your reason for doing so?
How do you perceive 100% completion as a concept? Do you find it worthwhile or just a waste? When do you go for one?

I personally try to do everything in the hardest setting, even if I'm not required to do so, and when I see that a 1CC is viable I'll also go for that too, but to me 100% really is about getting everything, unlocking anything that there is to unlock, mainly collectables, but also powerups and extra levels. I often go for 100% runs, and the one I'm most proud of if Spider-Man (2000/PS1) because of how difficult it is to unlock the Quick-Change suit. As for giving up, Yu-Gi-Oh! Forbidden Memories (1999/PS1) because there's too much RNG involved in getting all of the cards. Anyways, I personally love to go for 100% when I enjoy what I'm playing, it adds to the experience and it's fun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9582050
NTA but nothing's really inherently wrong with the later ones. Sonic CD came at a time when everyone was starved for a decent rendition of the game due to years of Sega neglecting the game and the constant last-minute blueballing in compilations (the og console version only just recently got officially re-released via the mini). If you go back, it's got tons of oversights that weren't there for the sake of upgrading the physics, including a few new gamebreaking bugs, mistiming time travel, and easily wrecking Time Attack mode times if you use the default/redone Spin Dash. Stealth coming on board post-CD was clearly the missing piece that made the Retro Engine versions of 1 and 2 far better, but even his autism has limitations: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yvj5__-uIu4
The simple fact is that the Retro Engine, while impressive in its own right, can never fully replicate the original engines, and the fact that A.I.R. was generally better received than Origins' 3&K is telling.

>>9569323
I'll try my best to explain what the fuck is really going on here.

One year before Metroid's release in 1985 the Dirty Pair television series aired on Japanese TV. During this time period science fiction in general was experiencing a boom on account of Return of the Jedi releasing just a few years prior.

Samus's helmet and her profession, intergalactic bounty hunter, were clearly inspired by Boba Fett. (Just one of the many references, like Ridley being named after the director of Aliens.)

As for her unarmored form, it was inspired by Yuri from Dirty Pair, a series whose popularity at the time could not be overstated. Dirty Pair was everywhere during that time period and had many copycats and references. In fact, Time Gal, lifts the design wholesale.

But Samus's unarmored form was only really supposed to be an easter egg for players skilled enough to complete the game in time. There wasn't much more thought to it beyond that and its design was based on the most popular female design of the time period.

Most people weren't even aware that Samus was female until the late 90s. They just assumed the person you played as was a guy.

The author of this article seems to have done more actual research into this than anyone:
https://www.acriticalhit.com/metroids-justin-bailey-is-a-real-person-heres-why-he-hasnt-spoken-up/

His conclusion is that Justin Bailey was probably a random player of the game who input their own name for the hell of it, followed by a row of dashes, and it JUST HAPPENED to register as a functional password with a bunch of shit unlocked, including the New Game+ alternate suit.

This seems like a rather remarkable set of coincidences, these games usually have some sort of checksum integrated into the password so inputting just anything won't work, and the fact this just happens to work with two six-character names and a row of plain dashes should be investigated to see just how likely any random password--no, not random, any password containing names and aesthetic repeating characters--is to be both valid and full of ingame goodies. Then, you'd have to have this mysterious Justin Bailey kid sending a letter to some gaming mag about the great password, but neglect to mention that it's actually his own name, or the magazine reprints it without this information and "makes up" the "just in bailey" rumor. The author suggests the "real" "Justin Bailey" may have been a 2-year old child at the time and a friend or family member just tried every name they new until one registered. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9585005
It's awesome. Also it has a cult following in Poland for some odd reason. You won't hear me complaining about it, because I liked it too end of the day, but it was really weird seeing it getting so popular when you've had shitloads of better games throughout the years that people slept on. My guess would be the cartoony graphics and it running on most machines, no matter your set-up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I only found out about the existence of this game from an LGR video about a year ago, was impressed by how clean the sprites looked. Then further impressed that there is a community that have made mods to let it run natively on modern Windows.

Said mods for the "1.4.4.4"/"Crazyhook" version seem to set off a few antivirus apps though so I am a little skeptical since the unmodified 1.3 version does not show anything in VirusTotal. Shame this isn't on GoG or Steam or anything.

Also apparently there was a DVD version but all the current cracks and mods are based on the CD version which can't use the additional/higher quality cutscenes from the DVD version? It's hard to find concrete information since it's all spread around sites that feel like the Geocities and Angelfire era instead of well put together wikis and modding guides like many far more popular retro games have these days.

Wish it was easier to find concrete information and to get a definitive DVD version that runs on modern Windows without a disk.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The issue with the music is not the music files. The GCN would require you to code an audio engine to feed the audio to the GCN's sound chip inside the GPU. Sega was either unwilling or unable in time to license someone else's audio engine, so they made their own for the GCN, and it turned out pretty terrible. In a lot of sixth gen games, you'll see the Bink Video logo and copyright notice at the beginning of the game, that means they probably licensed parts of their audio engine from Bink. Sega probably didin't feel like paying the money for that. In order to mod the game with a different audio engine, you'd need the game's source code.

Despite their popularity SMT still have (or had) a very niche targed audience. Not only does it not-hold your hand or ever let you feel any sort of comfort in the post apocalyptic city of Tokyo where almost everyone seems to hates you, it is very religion and symbolism heavy, which at least 99% of people who play it usually don't understand, even after they beat it.

If you just want a challenging dungeon for handheld with easier story and simple artstyle I recommen Etrian Odyssey.

But if you still want to play SMT no matter what, it depends on your preferences and goals. If you really like retro and are interested in the whole franchise you start with SMT 1 and 2 on SNES with the fantranslations. If you just want a good handheld SMT but arent really interested in the franchise, history or tradition of SMT, I recommend you playing SMT Strange Journey on DS. If you want a pure feeling of what SMT is about then stay away from the Redux version, it tried to widen the audience with implementing a little more anime, friendship, waifu and niceness into the game, which is the exact opposite of what SMTs are about.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9581228
Speaking for the FC/NES versions, you have a party of 3 people. Your lead(no magic, tank), the Prince(your white mage), and the Princess(your black mage). You also have a level cap. The lead can go up to level 50, the Prince to level 45, and the Princess to level 35. Once capped, you can't improve your stats in any way. Only the Prince can cast Revive, and the only revive item is the Leaf of the World Tree, of which you can only have one at a time.
This isn't a major issue until the Cave to Rhone and the rest of the final areas. Once you reach the Cave to Rhone, you start to encounter a lot of enemies with instant-kill attacks. A little bit of bad luck in the Cave and you'll have to take another swing at it.
In the NES version, the save point in Rhone will revive all fallen members and restore HP/MP. In the Famicom original, it just refilled. Meaning if the Prince died on the trip to Rhone, you might as well reset because you'll be needing that Leaf later.
Once you finally do reach Hargon's Castle, you need to fight three bosses more powerful than any other boss/monster you have encountered, including double attacks, AoE spells, and 2 out of the three can cast Healall and completely recover all their HP. If the Prince has died, might as well reset. After surviving that hell, you finally go after Hargon, who is just as tough as the previous guys, and also has Healall. If you manage to beat Hargon, THEN you use your leaf of the world tree if the prince went down, and do your best to restore/heal your team up before taking another step. Then you get to face the final boss who is just as tough as the previous guys and ALSO has Healall, along with the powerful Flames attack that hits everyone.
It's not an RPG you can just grind your way through due to the cap, reducing a lot of the last areas to depending on good RNG that the Prince won't get 1-shot by an instant kill spell before you reach the end.

>>9581856
It's actually not as bad as it sounds.

First of level, in that final area, the path to the final dungeon and the final dungeon itself are pretty small, once you know the way and depending on your luck you can get from the heal point to the dungeon in 3-4 encounters, then from the start of the dungeon to the final boss with 3-4 random encounters.
Then, a couple of the floors within the dungeon don't even seem to have any random encounter at all.
Also, all the bosses in the final dungeon stay dead so long as you don't load your save/password, so if you die, go back from the heal point, you still have made progress.
And while some bosses have heal all, if you setup properly they still go down in a few turns.

Finally, leveling up does help with the RNG: the higher your lvl is, the smaller the chance to be hit by OHKO attacks and status ailments becomes.

>In the NES version, the save point in Rhone will revive all fallen members and restore HP/MP.
>In the Famicom original, it just refilled
I didn't know that, that change doesn't even seem to be documented anywhere.

>Meaning if the Prince died on the trip to Rhone, you might as well reset
technically you CAN use the warp at the heal point to go back to a town, then use a wing of the wyvern to go back to the heal/save point. You'd think it doesn't work because you reached another town, but I've done that before, I think the wing returns to the previous save point so as long as you didn't save elsewhere you're fine

It was something about the original German release of Ultima 4 had the copyright protection triggered, so battles were retardedly hard.

>>9585846
Wizardry 4, the game of RNG. The big long write-up that gets reposted all the time is really trying to over-hype it. The majority of the challenge is figuring out which monsters to summon, then reaching the next stairway going up before they are all dead. You figure out the first pretty quickly, the second is just relying on RNG to not fuck you over by throwing too many hero parties at you. The last part of the challenge comes from the puzzles, due to the way the game was play-tested.
Sir-Tech decided it would be a good idea to get a big-name RPG fan to play-test their expert-level game to make sure they didn't create a game that could only be beaten with a guide. The expert they turned to was Scorpia of Computer Gaming World. Every single time Scorpia got stuck somewhere, she would walk over to the programmers and ask "Hey, how do I X?" They would tell her, she would go do it, rinse and repeat all the way through the game. In the end she told them it was "Challenging, but very fair." So every puzzle with every half-assed hint was considered perfectly fine because she could get the answer every time she got stuck. Good work Scorpia, and good job sucking your own clit in the CGW review of Wizardry 4. At least you admit to getting the answers in your review.
Trebor isn't even an issue outside of exploring, since you can reset his position by leaving a level and coming back in. And you are making a bee-line for the goal anyways, so you aren't likely to encounter him after the exploration phase. People just think he's scary because they think Wiz4 is a slow and methodical RPG like the rest, when getting to the next summoning circle ASAP is the main goal.

If you want a bit of money in the first couple of missions or so, start the mission with only one Uzi, then grab the ones dropped by enemies. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This is something that wondered about for years, and recently remembered it so I want to try to solve it again.

I used to love playing this Point-And-Click from Psygnosis called Innocent Until Caught, I had the floppy version. One thing that that always bugged me was when I tried to select Soundblaster or Roland/Soundblaster as my sound card I would get an error about the driver. If I set it to Roland I could hear music but of course nothing else.

Later I found out there was a CD version of the game too, and then wondered if this CD version was like many Lucasarts games at the time that had speech for the CD versions (the game had a speed toggle setting), and if maybe this is why the issues if the driver for some reason only got included on the CD. I recall at one point getting a CD of it, but I lost it. And it's been hard to find online from sites that don't package it into an EXE that makes VirusTotal go bananas.

I was able to find a CD copy just now, I extracted the files and then installed the floppy version on a virtual system and extracted those files too. The CD version has some extra files, but they are all associated with just having multiple language versions of the game. If I remove all but the English files, it's the exact same number of files. And while they are not the exact same size and don't have a 100% SHA match, the difference in sizes are only a few KB, and the majority of the files are a direct match.

...and still no driver.

No audio tracks on the CD either in case the speech, if any, was stored that way... assuming whoever ripped it didn't fuck it up.

Did this game ever have any speech at all? Did it's Soundblaster support ever work? Did they just never include a driver and never release any patches or updates to fix that? I don't recall ever reading about any patches released for this game, although for all I know since it's a 1993 title they could have been released on some now long dead BBS or newsgroup that was never archived.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The game on CD is still only a few megs and not nearly enough to hold full speech data. For comparison DOTT is 340 megs. However the sound works in Dosbox using the exodos version which is using the CD version.

Frames of delay, giving the rollback netcode the leeway to work. More frames of delay means higher input lag (ovbiously) but a stabler experience (less teleports)
A combination of brute-forcing+coding magic results in Slippi having 2 less frames of input lag compared to console, so that means that playing with 2f is effectively the same delay as console+CRT (provided you have a good monitor)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've made a few reproduction PS1 games.
Used high resolution scans of the CD inserts and booklets and had them printed off at a Staples on high quality photo paper. Cut them to size and stapled the booklet together. Printed a CD-R label using lightscribe and stickers.
Used a brand new jewel case.

And lemme tell you something about: it gave me a strong dopamine hit when I got it all put together. It felt just like holding a legit new game in my hands, and the reactions from my friends were the same. I made a few replacement cases for their disc-only games they owned.

These days you can go further with it because inkjet printable discs are a thing, and thermal printers are getting pretty cheap. You can pay people on etsy to make high quality thermal printed CD-Rs for you. It's like five bucks a disc but pair that with your own jewel case and inserts you can make a full game for less than ten dollars (get your jewel cases from a thrift store).

>>9582843
Yes you can do that, the issue is mainly with accuracy because vintage custom chips are typically NMOS while FPGAs are CMOS like all modern chips and don't have some of the particular quirks of NMOS, which software often relies on. In fact the Atari 2600 Jr. switched to a newer CMOS version of the TIA and it broke a few games (most notably Kool-Aid Man).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9582858
That functionality can be restored but then you get into the nitty gritty of "accuracy." I suppose you could tear down a chip, reproduce it's verilog as it would have originally been written, and just accept that it won't function exactly the same in FPGA while also offering an alternative, less accurate Verilog that will synthesize into a more accurate representation of the original chip in practice, offering the choice to the end user. I'm sure people will argue about that anyway though.

Not to mention the inherent Ship of Theseus problems that crop up when you start replacing components.

Excitebike

I'm not sure if other Family Computer Data Recorder games have save-hacks like these (Castle Excellent, Arkanoid: Revenge of Doh, Nuts & Milk, Mach Rider (etc?)), but these are the hacks I know of. A Mach Rider one sure would be nice to find, for one, since that game has a "Design" level creator function, like the three provided games do.

>>9578859
You realize this thing doesn't just plug into the console's audio output right? Even if a normal tape player/recorder will work, you still need a way to connect it to the console. Normally this was done by plugging it into the keyboard and plugging the keyboard into the 15 D-SUB-like connector on the front of the Famicom.

Besides, I don't want to deal with slow and ancient cassette tapes. I was asking if there was ever a flashcart or other accessory that can support or emulate it, like how there are flashdrives for the Sega Genesis now that can emulate the SegaCD without needing an actual SegaCD attached. And if not, if any emulators supported it at least.

And even if not, I would at least need to know some way to connect the pinout of the cassette recorder to whatever equivalent the NES had, if it even has any equivalent, or if there is no way to connect the tape recorder directly due to the keyboard having on-board hardware required for it's operation. I have no idea if the 3.5mm jacks that connect the keyboard to the tape recorder as just a pass-through or if the keyboard actually has some sort of modulator/demodulator to convert digital data coming from the port to audio for the cassette player and back.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9579029
I realize nearly everything about it. I've had one since shortly after it was released, written software to use it, and made hardware to emulate it.

There's basically nothing you can do about speed without rewriting the code. And if you're going to do that you may as well use something much faster, such as >>9578895 mentioned. IIRC Nintendo did this for a couple ports or VC games.

The pinout for a tape recorder in/out 3.5mm jack is very easy to find. So is the pinout for the exp port. Data is sent/received digital through that port one bit at a time. The keyboard uses a simple circuit to convert the signals, 4 bit resistor ladder IIRC. Many young children have designed and built such a circuit. If you're man enough, or even young child enough, to you can replace the tape deck and keyboard with pretty much any audio system you choose.

>>9563735
making my way through Ridge Racer 64, grabbed a cart the other day. it looks and feels good for a late gen 64 game, the 30fps is a bummer, but 60fps just wasn't realistic unless you have fzero tier barren ass blatant triangle tracks, so, it is what it is.
the game handles decently well, the cars feel different enough to drive and the stats appear to represent them well, but, seems to hit an impossible difficulty curve in the intermediate tracks... until you realize something very important: the broken ass drift mechanic.
when you "drift", you're not really "drifting" at all, you get locked into the geometry of the track and autosteered through sharp turns with zero control until you exit this mode at whatever angle your car is facing; which has nothing to do with what angle you are actually going. you can control haphazardly left and right with the control stick as you are getting autosucked to the track geometry until you are exited rather violently.
as far as driving, you can try to steer normally into a turn, hitting the brake and accelerating again to activate "drifting" but it seems to not work sometimes. HOWEVER: if you mash the brake, you always seem to get sucked into drift mode.
The metagame seems to be driving as fast as you can directly straight towards a wall before a steep curve(s), mashing the fuck out of the brake, and magically turning 90 or so degrees on a dime getting auto-weaved through brutal turns hopefully emerging somewhat straight.
I am still having fun with it, and will probably beat the rest of mirror mode in the near future, but, it feels cheap and dirty to just rely on autosteering through large portions of the track, but, if you don't you cant really win. so yeah. that's what the game boils down to.
it feels good to play an arcade racer again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's a very accomplished work of set-piece adventuring.
There's a really nice blend of giving the player agency but not too much space so the main thrust of the story does not lose momentum. It never feels like there's a dull moment or it devolves into an empty grind which was more or less the norm for JRPGs of the era.
Even to this day the pace of the game feels very modern and well calibrated.
On top of that all the characters, locations and moments are very memorable.

I'd say it's a pinnacle of a "guided JRPG".

It's overrated for a few reasons:
1) it does some unique/interesting things that make people perceive it to be better than it actually is
2) 90's jrpgs are massively overrated... mostly because people evaluate them in the context of their time instead of realistically comparing them against all games across all time. They also get a pass for a lot of things just due to the storyline and anime feel.
3) Games that reached mainstream in pre 2005 days get elevated to some untouchable status, but if you actually play other games from the same time period or even modern indie games you'll see that it's not that unique.

With that being said, it's a good game. Not life changing.

Nice collection. I still need to try DS version. I usually use Crono, Frog, and Marle.

Technically it's possible to beat Lavos even as soon as you reach the End of Time. With early equipment it's near impossible though, you have to grind a crazy amount. The only new option available in New Game+ is the Telepod at the fair, letting you fight Lavos solo. You get the same Developer's Room ending as you get from Ocean Palace Lavos though.
https://www.reddit.com/r/chronotrigger/comments/tf16yc/snes_emu_beat_lavos_on_newgame_at_earliest/
>I wasn't able to find hard evidence of being able to beat Lavos at the earliest possible point without "New Game+" -- someone undoubtedly has, I just couldn't find it --. So I decided to try myself. Specifically on SNES, beating Lavos after reaching the end of time, before returning to 1000AD. My rule was the title/save name for the chapter couldn't change from "End of Time" to "The Village of Magic". Thus I could grind in 65,000,000 BC to make it a bit faster. I did this via emulator, using turbo/fastforward but otherwise no assist/cheat/etc.

>After many hours of grinding to LVL 90 I finally did it (88:25 of game time, less realtime with fast-forward). Was able to get to the final form at about LVL 70, but the last form is a beast to do with the low level equipment. Grand Stone is an insta-wipe (chrono can occasionally survive if lucky+full HP) So I needed Lifeline via chrono+marle+robo. Magic damage wasn't as much of a problem as everyone had maxed Mdef at that level, but did still require pretty constant healing. Luminaire is a heavy hitter, but expensive: robo tackle was the MVP with level scaling dmg and MP efficiency -- didn't quite one-shot the left bit, but close enough to allow a one-two punch.

>Interestingly, this doesn't appear to have unlocked NewGame+, which is a bummer.
I saw a TAS do it too at a low 40s levels, but I'm guessing that's not possible normally without extreme luck
https://youtu.be/OJTUR67myH8

I still prefer the SNES release best as I prefer using my imagination instead of having animated cutscenes doing the same thing that was already done in-engine. I didn't think it was impossible, but I guess I don't love the game that much to grind for so long to attempt a low level equipment finish; impressive to me still. There probably is some fun to be had at a bare minimum attempt to a finish, that is taxing on the player and their luck, but one of my favorite components to Chrono Trigger is its impeccable pacing that you're shepherded through a variety of locations/times/story beats that I could not imagine really grinding aside from wanting to work backwards of the omen from the future on back or endgame side missions for overpowered items.
